content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, Given a DataFrame `df` with column `dt` representing DateTimes. Write a function `add_yearmonth` that creates a new column `ym` by extracting year and month from `dt` and concatenating them together as an integer in format: â€œyyyymmâ€.

First, ensure your Julia environment is correctly set up with the required packages. If not done already, you can add the necessary packages with:

```julia
using Pkg
Pkg.add(["DataFrames", "Dates"])
```

Afterwards, you can use the following code to achieve what you want:

```julia
using DataFrames, Dates

function add_yearmonth(df::DataFrame)
    df.ym = map(x -> parse(Int, string(Dates.year(x)) * string(Dates.month(x) < 10 ? "0$(Dates.month(x))" : Dates.month(x))), df.dt)
    return df
end
```

This function takes a DataFrame as an argument and creates a new column "ym" that is created by extracting the year and month from the "dt" column then converting it to an `Int` representation.

Please note that date and time manipulation in Julia is possible thanks to the Dates module which offers a type for holding dates (Day), a type for holding time (Time) and a type that combines the former two (DateTime). This makes it easy to extract the year and month with Dates.year and Dates.month functions.
